DataElement.preferredName: Initial Disease Recurrence Excision Surgical Margin Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the status of a tissue margin following the initial recurrent disease surgical resection.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Initial Disease Recurrence Excision Surgical Margin Status
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree._Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function._To occur again._Removal or excision by surgical measures._of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery._The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredName: First Disease or Disorder Recurrence Surgical Excision
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.:Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.:To occur again.:of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.:Removal or excision by surgical measures.

Concepts.definition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.
Happening again (especially at regular intervals).
of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

Property.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates the absence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.

Concepts.definition: Indicates the absence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.
Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Microscopically Positive Margins or Microscopic Residual Disease

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Microscopically Positive Margins or Microscopic Residual Disease
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates the presence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.: A finding resulting from the examination of a tissue sample under light or electron microscopy.: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.

Concepts.definition: Indicates the presence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.
A finding resulting from the examination of a tissue sample under light or electron microscopy.
Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Macroscopically Positive Margins or Gross Residual Disease

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Macroscopically Positive Margins or Gross Residual Disease
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of macroscopically visible residual tumor at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.: Visible to the naked eye.: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.

Concepts.definition: The presence of macroscopically visible residual tumor at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.
Visible to the naked eye.
Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.
